D-12484 Berlin, Germany Abstract The selective gas-phase oxidation of fluorene, anthracene, phenanthrene and naphthalene over supported and unsupported vanadium oxide-based catalysts frequently modified with other oxides such as Fe203 or MoO3 is reviewed and the effect of doping with alkali metal compounds is discussed. In particular, the oxidation of fluorene to 9-fluorenone is used as a key reaction for the discussion of the results. Reaction schemes derived from catalytic and kinetic measurements show strong similarities for all polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons investigated indicating that selective products of inner and outer-ring oxidation are formed in primary steps while their decomposition occurs consecutively particularly at high degrees conversion. In addition to the catalytic studies reaction engineering simulations with respect to fixed-bed and fluidized-bed reactor performance are discussed. By comparing textural and structural peculiarities of the catalysts (e.g. surface acidity, phase composition, redox properties, active sites and role of the support) with their catalytic performance it becomes evident that high oxygenate selectivities are favoured by moderate surface acidity and oxidation potentials which can be controlled by admixing alkali compounds or less acidic metal oxides like Fe203 to V205. In cesium-doped vanadium/iron oxides an amorphous phase was identified containing lattice-oxide vacancies occupied by electrons which, presumably, act as catalytically active sites. On the basis of these considerations essential common features for the different oxidation processes are pointed out and some rules for catalysts design are derived. Keywords: Selective gas-phase oxidation; Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons; Vanadium oxide catalysts; Alkali doping; Phase composition; Active sites; Electron spin resonance; Reactor performance 1. When oxygen reacts with outer- ring positions traces of 2,3-indenedicarboxylic anhydride are formed from fluorene and 1,2-naphthalic anhydride from phenanthrene. Three different products 2,3- naphthalic anhydride, 1,4-anthraquinone and pyromellitic anhydride result from anthracene. In addition to these desired compounds in almost all cases also products resulting from the decomposition of the carbon skeleton such as phthalic anhydride, maleic anhydride or even carbon oxides are produced the percentage of which depends strongly on the catalyst performance. The catalysts used for these reactions so far consist mainly of V205 frequently mixed with oxides of other transition metals such as iron [1], molybdenum [2], manganese [3], tungsten [4] and thallium [5]. However, since the catalysts were usually prepared by precipitation from solutions and subsequent calcination they contain also other phases than the pure oxides the composition and catalytical effect of which is not fully understood in every case. It is the aim of this paper to review critically the state of the art for the selective oxidation of polyaromatics by comparing first catalytic results and then discussing structural peculiarities of the various catalysts with respect to the course of the reaction. The selective oxidation of fluorene is emphasized as a reference for the other condensed hydrocarbons. Based on these considerations, essential common features for the different processes are pointed out and some rules for catalyst design are derived. 2. Catalytic results 2.1. On a commercial scale, about 30 000 t per annum of anthracene are used almost exclusively for its oxidation to anthraquinone either in liquid phase with chromic acid or by catalytic gas-phase reaction [ 13]. Suitable catalysts are based on V205 as a main component often containing additional constituents like molybdenum [14], manganese [3], tungsten [4] iron, alkali, alkaline earth or thallium [5]. Typical examples having been investigated for this reaction are: (i) unsupported vanadium/iron oxide catalysts as applied for the fluorene oxidation and (ii) vanadium/molybdenum/phosphorus oxides either in pure or supported form. In general, similar trends as for the oxidation of fluorene were also observed for that of anthracene over V2Os-Fe203 catalysts [1,15]. With increasing vanadium content the samples became more and more active. Between 20% 318 A. Briickner, M. Baerns /Applied Catalysis A: General 157 (1997) 311-334 and 90% of conversion, the various product selectivities were found to be independent of the latter. Close to complete conversion the selectivities of 9,10-anthraquinone, 1,4-anthraquinone and 2,3-naphthalic anhydride dropped down markedly in favour of those of phthalic as well as pyromellitic anhydride and finally carbon dioxide. On the basis of these catalytic results a reaction scheme for the oxidation of anthracene was derived indicating that all oxygenates can be considered as primary products (Fig. 4(b)). Similar to the oxidation of fluorene, doping the catalysts with alkali sulfate led to a marked increase of the inner- ring oxidation product (Fig. 5(b)) [16]. The oxidation of anthracene over V2Os- MoOa-P205 catalysts gave similar results as over vanadium/iron oxides [15] and can be characterized by the same reaction scheme as for vanadium/iron oxides (Fig. 4(b)). Supporting the catalysts on alumina or silica, respectively, led to better activities due to higher surface areas while the selectivity was not improved or even lowered. The influence of the support material will be discussed in Section 3.2. Phenanthrene. Phenanthrene is used for the industrial production of 9,10- phenanthrene quinone and 2,2'-diphenic acid either in liquid phase with chromates, nitric acid or hypochlorite as oxidizing agents or by catalytic gas-phase oxidation over vanadia-based catalysts [17]. From phenanthrene, generally, four different inner-ring oxidation products can be formed (Fig. 1). On unsupported V205 [ 18] or supported on carriers like SiO2 [19] and A1203 [20] mainly the decomposition products maleic and phthalic anhydride were formed. So-called VKS catalysts consisting of VaO5 and K2SO4 supported on SiO2 led to considerable amounts of selective inner-ring oxidation products (e.g. [21-23]). Baerns and co-workers studied the oxidation of phenanthrene over pure V205 and over mixed-oxide catalysts adding molybdenum and iron, respectively, to vanadium and doping them in certain cases with alkali ions [1,15]. The selectivity of 9,10-phenanthrene quinone decreased continuously with increasing conversion while that of 9-fluorenone and 1,2-naphthalic anhydride only dropped at conver- sions above 90% (Fig. 6). This indicates that the latter two products are more stable against further oxidation than 9,10-phenanthrene quinone. The selectivity of phthalic anhydride increased slightly at conversions below 80% and strongly above this value until it decomposes to COx dose to total conversion. The formation of diphenylic anhydride and the respective lactone (Fig. 1) was found to occur to a very small extent only except in the case of VEOs-Fe203 catalysts with an atomic ratio of V: Fe= 1 : 1.4 [24]. The selectivity of the lactone increased drastically at low conversions suggesting that it is a consecutive product probably formed from diphenic anhydride by decarbonylation. From this data a reaction scheme for the oxidation of phenanthrene has been derived which is, in principle, similar to that of the anthracene showing that all products except the lactone can be formed directly by oxidation of phenanthrene (Fig. 4(c)). Naphthalene. Besides the gas-phase oxidation of o-xylene, naphthalene oxida- tion is still an important industrial process for the production of phthalic anhydride. Only two selective oxidation products are formed from naphthalene without ring destruction, namely phthalic anhydride and 1,4-naphthalene quinone whereas non- selective oxidation leads to maleic anhydride and the carbon oxides. High yields of phthalic anhydride are obtained over silica-supported vanadia catalysts containing alkali sulfates in concentrations comparable to that of V205 or even higher. For example, by applying a commercial catalyst consisting of 10 mass% V205 and 33 mass% K2SO4 on SiO2 a phthalic anhydride selectivity of 90% was achieved [25]. A study of the influence of various alkali sulfates on the catalytic performance revealed that the selectivity to phthalic anhydride and 1,4 naphthalene quinone was enhanced with increasing atomic mass of the doping cations reaching maximum values of 80-90% for the cesium-doped catalysts [26,27]. The opposite trend was observed for the activity since the surface area of the catalysts was found to decrease markedly on alkali doping which was attributed to the formation of alkali pyrosulfates sealing the pore system of the support. The beneficial effect of alkali doping is in good agreement with the observations made for the other condensed aromatics. Comparison of catalytic and kinetic results All three-membered ring systems have in common that the product selectivities of the inner- and outer-ring oxidation are almost independent of the degree of conversion between 20% and 90%. Only above this limit they are decomposed to phthalic anhydride and further to the carbon oxides by consecutive oxidation. This indicates that the selective oxidation products are directly formed from the polycyclic hydrocarbons; these are strongly adsorbed on the catalyst surface, hereby, displacing all other products and preventing them from oxidation until nearly total consumption is reached. The only exceptions were observed in the phenanthrene oxidation where 9,10-phenanthrene quinone decomposes continu- ously due to its low stability and the lactone is only formed in a consecutive reaction. This has been indicated also by kinetic measurements in which the rate of formation of 9,10-phenanthrene quinone was found to decrease with increasing reactant concentration while the rate of consumption was enhanced [24]. For the same catalyst composition and reaction conditions the conversion decreases in the order fluorene>anthracene>phenanthrene. The same is observed for the selectivity of the inner-ring oxidation products. This agrees well with the reactivity of the inner-ring positions to be oxidized which decreases in the same order due to the loss of resonance energy caused by the oxidation [28]. Differences are most striking for the outer-ring oxidation. In the case of fluorene the respective compound was only detected in traces due to its low stability. The extent of outer-ring oxidation is comparable for anthracene and phenanthrene as indicated by the sum of the selectivities of the corresponding products. However, the product distribution differs markedly. In the case of phenanthrene only 1,2- naphthalic anhydride was detected while anthracene was found to be oxidized to three different outer-ring compounds. The different behaviour has been discussed in terms of different product stabilities [1]. The formation of tetracarboxylic anhydrides by simultaneous oxidation of both outer rings has been observed for the linear anthracene molecule only but not for the bent phenanthrene [1]. The oxidation kinetics of the three polycyclic hydrocarbons may be approxi- mated by first-order rate equations as long as the degree of conversion is below 90% [16]. However, this procedure failed at higher conversions where the rates of the consecutive reactions are faster than predicted by a first-order model. To describe the experimental results over the whole range of consumption different kinetic models were tested with respect to their suitability. As a result it was found that the phenanthrene oxidation could be described best with a Mars van Krevelen model whereas a Hougen-Watson model appeared to be less suitable [24]. The opposite was found for the fluorene oxidation [8,9]. Therefore, different models were used for both reactions. Nevertheless, at the present stage of our knowledge no final mechanistic conclusions should be drawn from the kinetic results. Reactor performance Despite the fact that in industry the oxidation of fluorene is still almost exclusively carried out in liquid phase, the promising catalytic results of the selective gas-phase oxidation obtained in laboratory reactors as described above should eventually lead to their transformation into industrial practice. Therefore, Baerns and co-workers analyzed the performance of two types of bench-scale reactors (fluidized-bed and fixed-bed) as well as the effect of scale-up to a commercial size unit by means of reaction engineering simulations applying different reactor models [10]. The three models used for the fluidized-bed reactor describe the fluidized bed either as a two-phase system (bubbles and emulsion) or as a three-phase system (bubbles, cloud and emulsion) while the fixed-bed reactor simulation was based on a one-dimensional homogeneous model. On comparing the predictions of fluorene conversion as a function of contact time (space-time conversion) for both types of reactors it was found that in the 322 A. Briickner, M. Baerns/Applied Catalysis A: General 157 (1997) 311-334 fluidized-bed reactor contact times about three times longer than in a fixed-bed reactor are necessary to achieve the same degree of conversion; this is due to limitations in mass transport between bubbles and emulsion phase. Furthermore, gas backmixing is significant in the fluidized-bed reactor. Accordingly, the 9- fluorenone selectivity was lower in the former case since the longer contact times and backmixing promote consecutive reactions. By simulations of fluidized-bed reactor the effects of temperature and hydro- dynamic conditions on catalytic performance were studied. The following com- mon features being qualitatively valid for the various models applied can be derived: Only a slight increase of fluorene conversion with temperature was predicted by all models between 573 and 723 K which is an indication that the primary reaction is mass transport limited. In the same temperature range the selectivity of 9-fluorenone was found to decrease from about 93% to about 55%; this is essentially due to the higher activation energy of the consecutive reactions. Increasing the gas velocities corresponding to fluidization numbers between 8 and 55 lowered expectedly the fluorene conversion strongly while the selectivity of 9- fluorenone passed at fluidization numbers between 10 and 15 through a flat maximum amounting to approximately 80-87% depending on the simulation model. On scaling-up from a bench-scale fluidized-bed reactor (reactor diameter: 7 cm) to a commercial-size unit (reactor diameter: 6 m) it was predicted that increasing fluidization numbers require significantly longer contact times than in lab scale to reach the same degree of fluorene conversion as in a bench-scale reactor while total conversion was not achieved at all. The selectivity of 9-fluorenone dropped with conversion for all fluidization numbers. The best value of 63% achieved at a conversion of 86% was obtained for a fluidization number of 10. In summary, the results of the simulation study predicted that both space-time conversion and selectivity of 9-fluorenone decreases slightly on changing from a fixed-bed to a fluidized-bed bench-scale reactor but markedly on changing to a commercial size fluidized-bed unit. It is clear that this interaction and the consecutive oxidation reactions are strongly influenced by the acid-base properties of the catalyst surface and numerous investigations of these properties have been carried out in the past using the adsorption of probe molecules. Ai et al. studied the acid-base properties of V2Os-Fe203 catalysts supported on pumice stone with two different methods [29]. Surface acidity was determined by both static adsorption of ammonia and the amount of pyridine required to inhibit the acid catalyzed isomerization of 1-butene over these catalysts used as a probe reaction. It was found that the catalysts became more and more acidic on increasing the vanadium content reaching the highest acidity for pure V205. The opposite trend was observed for the basicity as indicated by decreasing amounts of adsorbed CO2. Similar results were also obtained by Baerns and co-workers for unsupported V2Os-Fe203 catalysts [30]. They determined the intensity of the IR bands of pyridine adsorbed on Lewis and BrCnsted acid sites and found that the band intensity decreased with increasing iron content. Generally, the band intensity related to BrCnsted sites was lower than that of Lewis sites. The acidic character of V205 has been also confirmed by Busca and co-workers [31,32] who detected strong Lewis and medium BrCnsted acid sites on the surface of pure and supported V205. Summary and conclusions for catalyst design As a general result it has to be noted that vanadia-based catalysts are suitable systems for the selective gas-phase oxidation of polycyclic aromatics i.e., phenan- threne, anthracene and fluorene. The reaction mechanisms for the various com- pounds appear to be very similar. Therefore, the selectivity of all these processes is presumably influenced in the same way by the catalyst properties for which some common rules can be derived. An important factor is the surface acidity of the catalysts. The basic hydro- carbons adsorb with the aromatic ring system at acidic sites. When this adsorption is strong as in the case of highly acidic catalysts (e.g. pure V205 or mixed oxides supported on acidic carders) the selective oxidation products cannot desorb quickly enough and are hence subject to further non-selective oxidation. This can be prevented when the number and strength of acidic sites is reduced by admixing less acidic metal oxides like Fe203 and MOO3, respectively, to V205 or by doping it with basic alkali compounds. On the other hand, the redox properties of the catalysts are of great importance. It was shown that pure V205 has a strong oxidation potential due to its VS+=O groups and that it leads to a considerable proportion of total oxidation products. On doping with alkali ions the vanadium is partially reduced to V4+ which is less active but more selective than V5+. In addition, when alkali ions are incorporated in the catalyst structure separate amorphous phases may be created as shown for cesium- doped V205-Fe203 catalysts. These contain particular vacancy centres which are able to transform any adsorbed oxygen species rapidly into lattice oxygen required for selective oxidation. This is in accordance with the enhanced oxygen exchange rates having been detected for alkali-doped vanadia catalysts [8]. Thus it is very probable that not the well defined crystalline phases of the multi-metal-oxide catalysts are the active ones in catalysis but rather an amorphous species the nature of which is poorly understood and even its existence has been detected so far only for the cesium-doped V205-Fe203. Further, it has to be taken into account that, in general, the characterization studies reviewed in this paper had been carried out on fresh catalysts. There are no data available on how the catalytic properties change with increasing time on stream. These aspects should be a subject of further research work. For improved catalyst design the following rules should be taken into account: Catalysts should have moderate acidity to suppress non-selective oxidation leading to the decomposition of the aromatic ring system or even to its total oxidation. Catalysts should be mild oxidizing agents based on nucleophilic oxygen and they should contain a certain amount of V4+ since this was shown to be less active but more selective than V5+. A. Its strong acidity and oxidation potential may be reduced by compound formation with other metal oxides and/or by doping with basic ions like alkali. If for reasons of improved activity high surface area supports are used, e.g. for alkali-doped V205-Fe203, the catalysts may be supported on carriers with high surface area. However, it has to be considered that only inert (neutral) or weakly basic supports are suitable and that pore-diffusional limitations are avoided.
